channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: S&P 500 Rally Wavers Amid Stock Buyer Exhaustion: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street’s epic rebound from April’s meltdown is showing signs of exhaustion on speculation stocks have run too fast amid risks stemming from a trade war to an economic slowdown and sticky inflation.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.

item.title: UniCredit Sends Letter to Berlin Saying It’s Open to Talks
item.description: UniCredit SpA has sent congratulatory letters to the new German government that also signaled its willingness to hold talks, according to people familiar with the matter, indicating the Italian bank is seeing a potential opening to improve fraught relations.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze, Sonia Sirletti

item.title: Morgan Stanley's Slimmon Says He's More Cautious on Stocks
item.description: "I'm a little bit more cautious today than I was six weeks ago," Andrew Slimmon, Morgan Stanley Investment Management senior portfolio manager, says while discussing the state of financial markets on "Bloomberg Markets." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trading Platform EToro Surges 42% After $620 Million Upsized IPO
item.description: EToro Group Ltd. shares rose as much as 42% in its first session as a public company, after the trading and investment platform and some of its backers raised nearly $620 million in an upsized IPO.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin, Anthony Hughes

item.title: We Don't See A Recession in Our Outlook: Lakshman Achuthan
item.description: Lakshman Achuthan co-founder and Chief Operations Officer of ECRI, the Economic Cycle Research Institute joins Bloomberg Surveillance to discuss the labor market and if the ECRI has a recession priced in. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nigeria’s Seplat Sees First-Half Revenue Topping Last Year’s $1.1 Billion
item.description: Seplat Energy Plc, Nigeria’s largest oil and gas explorer, expects first-half revenue to exceed last year’s $1.1 billion after ramping-up production.
item.dc:creator: Emele Onu

media:content.media:description: Gasoline storage tanks at an oil refinery in Lagos, Nigeria.

item.title: Ryan Reynolds’ Ad Firm MNTN, Holders Seek $187 Million in IPO
item.description: Connected TV advertising platform MNTN Inc. and some of its shareholders are seeking to raise as much as $187 million in an initial public offering, after delaying the launch amid tariff-induced market volatility.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes, Bailey Lipschultz

item.title: Dutta: An Uncomfortable Economic Reality Is Still Setting In
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians in the Times Square neighborhood of New York, US, on Friday, May 9, 2025. New York City officials cut their forecast for the number of international tourists this year by 17%, saying President Donald Trump's tariffs and hard-line policies on immigration are deterring visitors. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg

item.title: JBS Shares Slide on Concerns Over Deepening Beef Losses
item.description: JBS SA shares slumped the most in two years as the world’s largest meat supplier faces deepening losses at its US beef business, even as chicken continues to drive profits.
item.dc:creator: Gerson Freitas Jr, Clarice Couto

media:content.media:description: The JBS Greeley meatpacking facility in Greeley, Colorado, US, on Friday, Feb. 28, 2025. Plans for the biggest deportations in US history threaten to upend the meatpacking industry. Photographer: Chet Strange/Bloomberg

item.title: S&P 500 Grinds Higher As Chipmakers’ Shares Rise on Gulf Deals
item.description: US stocks edged higher on Wednesday, as chipmakers’ shares advanced following a series of high-profile deals announced during President Donald Trump’s tour of the Persian Gulf while gains in the broader market slowed after a blistering rally.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Brookfield Tests Market for Debt Deals Halted by Trade Strife
item.description: The thaw spreading across credit markets on a reprieve from US-China trade tensions has lured back at least one borrower, Brookfield Properties Retail, as it greenlights two debt sales shelved in April.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Graf, Jeannine Amodeo, Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: The Brookfield Asset Management logo on a smartphone arranged in New York, US, on Wednesday, Nov. 8, 2023. Brookfield Asset Management raised $26 billion in the third quarter and said it's on track to bring in close to $150 billion in fresh capital this year, despite a tough fundraising environment. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

item.title: US Firms Snap Up Short-Term Treasuries to Extend Duration of Cash Holdings
item.description: US corporations with over a trillion in assets snapped up an unprecedented amount of short-term Treasuries when President Donald Trump announced a 90-day delay for most of his “Liberation Day” tariffs, according to Clearwater Analytics.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury Department building in Washington, DC.

item.title: Norway Bets $800 Million on Blackstone Logistics, Warehouse Fund
item.description: Norway’s sovereign wealth fund committed $800 million to Blackstone Inc. to invest in warehouses and logistics, ratcheting up a bet on North American supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Dawn Lim

media:content.media:description: A worker operates a forklift past boxes of imported pork at a cold storage warehouse in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, March 5, 2025. China will impose tariffs on a slew of US farm products as part of its countermeasures against Washington, threatening to disrupt a major portion of trade between the two agricultural powerhouses. Photographer: Raul Ariano/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Declines After Biggest US Crude Stockpile Gain Since March
item.description: Oil dropped after a government report showed US crude inventories rose by the most in two months, overshadowing the lingering relief from the trade truce between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: A gas flare burns from a pipe aboard an offshore oil platform in the Persian Gulf's Salman Oil Field, operated by the National Iranian Offshore Oil Co., near Lavan island, Iran, on Thursday, Jan. 5. 2017. Nov. 5 is the day when sweeping U.S. sanctions on Iran’s energy and banking sectors go back into effect after Trump’s decision in May to walk away from the six-nation deal with Iran that suspended them. Photographer: Ali Mohammadi/Bloomberg

item.title: Aramco Signs Pacts Worth Up to $90 Billion With US Companies
item.description: Oil giant Saudi Aramco signed agreements with major US companies potentially totaling about $90 billion.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Caminada

media:content.media:description: A crude oil storage tank at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and oil terminal in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: This Flight Hack Airlines Don’t Want You to Know About
item.description: Airlines are facing a lot of headwinds these days--from falling consumer demand and higher costs to air traffic control issues. Now, the industry has another problem on the horizon-- the upstart Skiplagged. It's a controversial website that uncovers airfare hacks, like skipping the last leg of a flight in order to get a cheaper price. Aktarer Zaman, Skiplagged CEO joined Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the business model. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fed’s Jefferson Warns of Slow Growth, Boost to Inflation
item.description: Federal Reserve Vice Chair Philip Jefferson sees tariffs and related uncertainty possibly slowing growth and raising inflation this year. “With the increased risks to both sides of our mandate, I believe that the current stance of monetary policy is well positioned to respond in a timely way to potential economic developments,” Jefferson said Wednesday during a conference organized by the New York Fed.

item.title: Trump Memecoin Speculator Says Presidential Dinner Is Costing Him Just $1,200
item.description: Morten Christensen says he and four crypto-loving friends will be attending the dinner next week being held for the top holders of President Donald Trump’s memecoin for just about $1,200 each.
item.dc:creator: Olga Kharif

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during an Easter prayer service and dinner in the Blue Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 16, 2025. Trump said negotiators made "big progress" in a meeting with Japanese officials seeking a deal to avoid higher levies he has threatened against US trading partners.

item.title: Saks Creditors Face $1 Billion in Losses
item.description: It was supposed to be just what Saks needed to turn things around. By taking over struggling rival Neiman Marcus, the pitch went, the iconic retailer would become a luxury powerhouse — one with enough bargaining and pricing power to cut costs and boost profitability.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Ronalds-Hannon

media:content.media:description: A Saks Fifth Avenue shopper in New York.

item.title: Flurry of IPO Activity Hits Wall Street
item.description: Robinhood rival EToro Group raised nearly $620 million in its IPO. Meanwhile, Ryan Reynolds's MNTN is considering launching its IPO as soon as this week. And CATL, a Chinese maker of EV batteries, is poised to raise at least $4 billion in Hong Kong. Bloomberg's stock reporter Matthew Griffin joined Wall Street Beat on Bloomberg Open Interest with his analysis. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Scrap Copper Was Piling Up in the US. Now It Can Finally Move
item.description: A mountain of scrap metal in Salt Lake City that had been growing in recent weeks is finally set to shrink, thanks to the temporary truce in the trade dispute between the US and China.
item.dc:creator: Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: Copper scraps at the Utah Metal Works Inc. in Salt Lake City, Utah, US, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. Photographer: Niki Chan Wylie

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 05/14/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Manhattan Casino Bidder Pitches Equity Stake to New Yorkers
item.description: Soloviev Group, the real estate developer that owns a major office tower at 9 West 57th St. in Manhattan, is proposing a way for New York City residents to benefit from its potential $11.2 billion casino project.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan

item.title: Canada’s New Tariffs on US Drop to ‘Nearly Zero’ With Exemptions, Oxford Says
item.description: Canada has effectively suspended almost all of its retaliatory tariffs on US products, tamping down inflation risks and improving its growth outlook, according to Oxford Economics.
item.dc:creator: Derek Decloet

media:content.media:description: A truck crosses the Peace Bridge at the Canada-US border in Fort Erie, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, April 2, 2025. US President Trump on April 2 plans to roll out tariffs on global trading partners, the centerpiece of his effort to bring back manufacturing to the US and reshape a world trade system he has long decried as unfair.

item.title: Stock Movers: Super Micro Computer, AMD Rises, Aurora Innovation Falls after Uber Announcement
item.description:
SuperMicro (SMCI) extends gains after the Saudi Arabia-based data center company DataVolt signs a multi-year partnership agreement with the beleaguered US chipmaker.
AMD’s shares rise after the board approves a $6 billion share repurchase plan that represents 3.3 percent of the company’s current market value, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
Aurora Innovation (AUR) shares fall after Uber announced a $1 billion convertible offering, with the notes exchangeable into shares of Aurora. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Touts Record Boeing Order From Qatar Airways
item.description: Qatar Airways signed a deal to buy 160 aircraft from Boeing during a visit to Doha by President Donald Trump. It is the largest order in the US planemaker's history. Trump is also expected to sign agreements that span defense, aviation, infrastructure and technology during his trip to the Gulf. Bloomberg's Annmarie Hordern is traveling with the president and reports from Doha. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Private Credit’s Latest Golden Moment Is Hiding the Cracks
item.description: Investors are still flocking to the $1.6 trillion asset class, even as questions persist about the strength of its underlying assets.
item.dc:creator: Kat Hidalgo, Edward Clark

media:content.media:description: US Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent speaks at the 28th annual Milken Institute Global Conference at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills, California on May 5, 2025. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP) (Photo by PATRICK T. FALLON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Nvidia and AMD Stocks Rally on Trump's Saudi Arabia Visit
item.description: President Trump is striking deals to give Saudi Arabia wider access to advanced AI chips. Nvidia, AMD are seeing gains while Super Micro announced it reached a deal worth $20 billion dollars. Bloomberg Technology Co-Host Ed Ludlow joined Bloomberg Open Interest with the latest. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Says Qatar’s Order Is Largest in Boeing’s History
item.description: President Donald Trump says Boeing won an order from Qatar Airways amid a flurry of deals between Gulf nations. The agreement signed by the Doha-based carrier is for 160 aircraft, according to the White House, in what it said is the largest order in the American company’s history.

item.title: Brazil Needs Fiscal Sense to Gain From Trade War, Speaker Says
item.description: Brazil has emerged as an early winner from Donald Trump’s trade war with China but needs to get its fiscal situation in order to attract investment and fully capitalize on the global upheaval, according to lower house Speaker Hugo Motta.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Carvalho, Vanessa Dezem

media:content.media:description: Hugo Motta Photographer: Raul Luciano/Agencia Estado/AP Images
